Subject: Re: [neat] Quantitative vs. Qualitative Results
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=236201729; y=-9rjCgeBYIPFarksgiV7Td2aprYLdaug-BylxLYc3Ngd37tB

Hi all,

On 22 avr. 2013, at 11:55, Julian Togelius wrote:

> In the end, t=
he real test of the value of a paper (assuming that it is factually correct=
 in the first place) is how much subsequent research (or how many applicati=
ons) it inspires. Therefore, I think we should move to a system where all p=
apers are initially submitted to venues with low acceptance thresholds (and=
 therefore typically high, but not pre-determined, acceptance rates), and y=
ears later, when they have been public long enough to show their real worth=
 in informing other people's research, they could be elected to be part of =
more "selective" proceedings. This would likely help researchers refrain fr=
om adding needless quantitative results just to please reviewers.

I would =
like this kind of system very much. Actually, it not that far from a more c=
lassic system in which conferences have a very high acceptance rate (to dis=
cuss and mature ideas, possibly without quantitive comparisons) and journal=
 papers with lower acceptance rate in which we publish more mature ideas (t=
ypically with more quantitative experiments and better arguments).

This is=
 also close to what Nicolas describes. "A decent poster session with a lowe=
r selection rate (~50%? unlike PPSN) would possibly enable to take some ris=
ks with accepting contributions, and giving anyone the opportunity to prese=
nt new ideas, without removing the fact that if you want to get your work a=
ccepted for a conference talk or a journal publication (with high selection=
 rate), you have to work hard to convince reviewers and editors (as it is a=
lready the case for many journals). To some extent, this is already done el=
sewhere, for example in the annual meeting of the Society for Neuroscience =
(thousands of attendants, many many posters, keynote talks).=94

Best regar=
ds,
=97 JBM
http://pages.isir.upmc.fr/~mouret/
